div.em: Current conditions as of 19 Apr 12:55 pm CDT

div.p: This Afternoon
div.span: Sunny, with a high near 53. Northwest wind 5 to 10 mph.

div.p: Tonight
div.span: A slight chance of showers after 2am. Mostly cloudy, with a low around 38. Light and variable wind becoming southwest 10 to 15 mph after midnight. Chance of precipitation is 20%.

div.p: Monday
div.span: Mostly sunny, with a high near 63. Breezy, with a southwest wind 5 to 10 mph becoming west northwest 15 to 20 mph in the afternoon. Winds could gust as high as 30 mph.

h3.a: COVID-19 Home Isolation For Ill Persons

p.b: COVID-19Â Preparation in the home
HAVE YOU MADE A PLAN FOR WHAT YOU ARE GOING TO DO IF YOU HAVE SOMEONE IN YOUR HOUSEHOLD WHO IS ILL?

What to do/prepare for in the home if you have someone with fever, cough or have difficulty breathing in your family and home. Approximately 80% of Iowans infected with COVID-19 will experience only a mild to moderate illness.Â Most mildly ill Iowans do not need to go to their healthcare provider or be tested to confirm they have COVID-19. We need to preserve our supplies of personal protective equipment and testing supplies. If you are really ill and having difficulty breathing and need healthcare, call first. Your provider can assess whether you need to be seen in the office or if you can recover at home. Also, there may be options for you to talk to a medical provider from home using technology.
All sick Iowans must stay home and isolate themselves from others in their house.
Â The rest of the household members must self-isolate from the public in their home for 14 days.

In preparation for an illness in your home you should have some supplies on hand such as a fever/pain reducer such as Tylenol or otherâ Over the Counterâ medications you like to use when ill. Have a humidifier ready to use and plenty of clear liquids and other supplies. Plan how to obtain other medications or supplies by drive through or curbside delivery (without contact with other people) or having someone else bring groceries/supplies to your home and leave at the door.Â

If possible isolate the ill person in a separate bedroom and also if possible a separate bathroom.Â If there is a master suite with a bathroom or a basement room with a bathroom that can be kept closed off from the rest of the home, that would be good area to use as a âsick roomâ. Keep doors closed and disinfect all surfaces frequently during the day. One person should be designated to go into the âsick roomâ to bring in supplies, food, entertainment, etc and care for the ill person.Â This should be an adult who is not at increased risk of severe illness from COVID-19. You may want to use a homemade mask, some gloves, and a robe or clothing covering that can be washed frequently. No one else should enter the room if possible. Keep surfaces (especially bedside tables, surfaces in the bathroom and toys for children) clean by washing or wiping them down with a household disinfectant.

The designated caregiver should try to not come any closer than 6 feet from the ill person if possible and wash their hands with soap and water or an alcohol-based hand rub frequently, including after every contact with the sick person or the personâs room or bathroom.Â Use paper towels for drying hands after handwashing, or have separate cloth towels for each person in the household. For example, have different colored towels for each person.

Food can be brought in to the ill person on disposable plates etc. and disposed of in a plastic garbage bag in that room and tied up.Â It is best if nothing comes back outside the room until the ill person gets better. Garbage bags can be tied up and brought immediately outside the home and disposed of if needed.Â Laundry if needed to be brought outside the room should be rolled up and put in a plastic bag or laundry bag that can be washed with the soiled laundry. Do not shake out any dirty laundry to prevent distributing the virus.Â Wash laundry on the hottest setting possible and dry on the warmest setting possible without harming the items. Caregivers should wash hands after handling trash or laundry. If using non-disposable plates and utensils be sure to wash them in hot soapy water or in the dishwasher on hot.Â
You may want to think about using a HEPA air filter on your furnace. Room size HEPA air filters can be purchased for the sick room to help filter the circulating air.
Maintain good ventilation in common areas of the house such as keeping windows open in restrooms, kitchen, keep vent going in bathroom etc. as able considering outside weather.

Families in self isolation should not have direct contact with any animals (ie., dogs, cats, pigs, cattle, sheep and goats) out of abundance of caution.Â Arrange for your pets to be cared for and housed outside of your home, if possible
The ill person must stay home and isolated until:
You have had no fever for at least 72 hours (that is three full days of no fever without the use of medicine that reduces fevers ie. Tylenol, Ibuprofen etc.), AND
Other symptoms have improved (for example, when your cough or shortness of breath have improved), AND
At least 7 days have passed since your symptoms first appeared.

Sick rooms need to be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected when the ill person has recovered. Iowa Department of Health states that most commercially produced Disinfectants are effective against COVID-19 and can be used in the home.Â You can also use a bleach solution made by mixingÂ
5 tablespoons (1/3 cup) bleach per gallon of water or
4 teaspoons bleach per quart of water.

h3.a: April Rotary Student of the Month

span.style: outline: none; display: inline; width: auto; font-size: 14px; line-height: 18px; font-family: system-ui, -apple-system, system-ui, ".SFNSText-Regular", sans-serif; color: rgb(28, 30, 33);
span.span: April Rotary Student of the Month is Megan Boger! Megan is the daughter of Bill and Jenny Boger and was nominated for this recognition by staff members. Megan participates in basketball, student council, volleyball, and was a member of the Homecoming Court. A quote from one of Megan's teachers, "Megan has a relentless work ethic that is going to help her accomplish all of her goals!" Congratulations to Megan!

h3.a: Notice of Public Hearing and Letting

div.h4: 2020 Cherokee Community School District Improvements Projects - Division I and II

div.p: NOTICE OF PUBLIC HEARING AND LETTING

for
2020 Cherokee Community School District Improvements Projects â Divisions I and II

Public notice is hereby given that the School Board of the Cherokee Community School District, in Cherokee County, Iowa, will meet on April 20, 2020, at 5:30pm, at which time and place a public hearing will be held in the Cherokee Community School District board room located at 600 W. Bluff Street, Cherokee, Iowa 51012 on the proposed plans and specifications, form of contract and estimate of cost for the 2020 Cherokee Community School District Improvements Projects â Divisions I and II, for said school district. Sealed proposals will be received by the Superintendent of the Cherokee Community School District for the 2020 Cherokee Community School District Tennis Court Improvements (Division I) & Parking Lot Improvements (Division II) until 2:00 P.M. on Friday, April 17, 2020, located at 600 W. Bluff Street, Cherokee, IA 51012; at which time the bids will be publicly opened and read. Proposals will be acted on by the Cherokee Community School Board at the aforementioned public hearing or at such later time and place as may then be fixed.
Work to Be Done:

Tennis Court Improvements (Division I): Work to be completed generally consists of approximately: 49 Units of Clearing and Grubbing; 280 C.Y. of Topsoil, On-Site; 1145 C.Y. of Excavation, Class 10; 5713 S.Y. of Subgrade Preparation, 12â; 5713 S.Y. of Modified Subbase, 2â; 1236 L.F. of Subdrain, Perforated, Single-Wall HDPE, 6â; 1 EA Subdrain Connections and Outlets, CMP, 6â; 1 EA Intake, Nyloplast, 18â; 1 EA Intake Adjustment, Minor; 1 EA Removal of Existing Intake; 5429 S.Y. of Pavement, PCC, 6â; 438 S.Y. of Removal of Sidewalk; 67 S.Y. of Sidewalk, PCC, 5â; 109 S.Y. of Driveway, Paved, PCC, 6â; 4927 S.Y. of Pavement Removal; 1 LS Painted Pavement Markings, Symbols, and Legends, Solvent/Waterborne; 1 LS Temporary Traffic Control; 0.5 AC of Conventional Seeding, Seeding, Fertilizing, and Hydro-Mulching; 1 LS Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan, Management; 730 S.Y. of Temporary RECP, Type 2C; 485 L.F of Silt Fence Installation and Removal; 5 EA of Inlet Protection Device and Maintenance; 120 L.F. of Chain Link Fence, Black PVC Coated, 48â; 1148 L.F. of Chain Link Fence, Black PVC Coated, 120â; 13 EA Gates, Black PVC Coated, 84âx4â with 36â Transom; 1395 L.F. of Removal of Fence; 1 LS Mobilization; 1 L.S. Concrete Washout; 4881 S.Y. of Tennis Court Surfacing; 6 EA Tennis Net and Posts; 5 EA Remove and Replace Existing Benches/Garbage Cans.

Parking Lot Improvements (Division II) â Base Bid: Base bid work to be completed generally consists of approximately: 350 C.Y. of Topsoil, On-Site; 249 C.Y. of Topsoil, Off-Site; 1550 C.Y. of Excavation, Class 10; 8073 S.Y. of Subgrade Preparation, 12â; 248 S.Y. of Modified Subbase, 2â; 7825 S.Y. of Modified Subbase, 4â; 237 L.F. of Storm Sewer, Trenched, Dual-Wall HDPE, 6â; 87 L.F. of Storm Sewer, Trenched, Dual-Wall HDPE, 10â; 144 L.F. of Storm Sewer, Trenched, Dual-Wall HDPE, 12â; 575 L.F. of Removal of Storm Sewer, <12â; 5 EA Special Pipe Connection for Storm Sewer; 1 L.F. of Storm Sewer Field Exploration, 15â; 44 L.F. of Subdrain, Perforated, Single-Wall HDPE, 4â; â; 1937 L.S. of Subdrain, Perforated, Single-Wall HDPE, 6â; 1 EA Subdrain Connections and Outlets, CMP, 4â; 6 EA Subdrain Connections and Outlets, CMP, 6â; 1 EA Storm Sewer Intake, SW-507; 1 EA Storm Sewer Intake, SW-541; 9 EA Connection to Existing Intake; 2 EA Remove Intake; 7251 S.Y. of Pavement, PCC, 6â; 173 S.Y. of Removal of Sidewalk; 232 S.Y. of Sidewalk, PCC, 5â; 58 S.F. of Detectable Warning; 8662 S.Y. of Pavement Removal; 1 L.S. of Painted Pavement Markings, Symbols, and Legends, Solvent/Waterborne; 1 LS Temporary Traffic Control; 0.8 AC of Conventional Seeding, Seeding, Fertilizing, and Hydro- Mulching; 1 L.S. Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan, Management; 50 L.F. of Filter Sock/Wattle, 9â Dia.; 1381 L.F of Silt Fence Installation and Removal; 120 S.Y. of Stabilized Construction Entrance; 5 EA of Inlet Protection Device and Maintenance; 46 L.F. of Removal and Reinstallation of Fence, Chain Link, 72â; 65 L.F. of Removal of Fence; 26 L.F. of Handrail, Metal, 42â; 1 LS Mobilization; 1 LS Concrete Washout; 6 EA Remove and Replace Signs; 1 L.S.
NPHL-1
Removal of Loading Dock; 1 L.S. PCC Loading Dock; 1 L.S. Remove, Salvage, and Replace Existing Benches; 1 L.S. Remove, Salvage, and Replace Existing Light Pole.

Parking Lot Improvements (Division II) â Alternate 1: Alternate 1 work to be completed generally consists of approximately: 74 C.Y. of Excavation, Class 10; 2662 S.Y. of Pavement, PCC, 7â (additional cost vs. 6â PCC Paving).
See Bid Form for exact quantities.

Proposals: All proposals shall be made on official proposal forms furnished by the Engineer and shall contain worded and figured prices for the work bid on. All proposals shall be plainly legible, sealed, and addressed to Cherokee Community Schools, Attn: Kimberly Lingenfelter, Superintendent, 600 W. Bluff Street, Cherokee, IA 51012. Bidder shall submit a Bidder Status Form with their bid. Failure to submit a fully completed Bidder Status Form with the bid may result in the bid being deemed unresponsive and rejected. A certified check or a bid bond of a reputable bonding company authorized to do business in the State of Iowa in an amount not less than ten percent (10%) of the total amount of the bid shall be included in a separate sealed envelope, plainly marked âbid bondâ. The bid guarantee shall be forfeited as liquidated damages if the successful bidder fails proper execution.

The checks or bid bonds of the lowest two or more bidders may be held for the earlier of 7 days after the effective date of the agreement or 61 days after the bid opening, whereupon Bid Security furnished by such bidders will be returned. Other checks or bid bonds will be returned after the tabulation of bids is completed.

Performance and Payment Bonds: The successful bidder must execute performance and payment bonds, each in an amount equal to one hundred (100%) percent of the contract amount to ensure a timely, efficient, and complete performance. The bonds shall be issued from a reputable bonding company authorized to do business in the State of Iowa.

Liquidated Damages: Liquidated damages will be assessed the contractor in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per working day that the work remains uncompleted after the end of the contract period with due allowances for extensions due to conditions beyond the control of the contractor.
Withdrawal of Bids: No submitted bids may be withdrawn for a period of thirty (30) days from the scheduled closing time for the receipt of bids.

Payment: The Contractor will be paid monthly in an amount equal to ninety-five percent (95%) of the Work completed during the previous month according to the Engineerâs estimate. The final payment will be made not less than thirty (30) days after completion of the Work and acceptance by the Cherokee Community School District. No final payment will be due until the Contractor has certified that the materials, labor, and services have been paid for in accordance with the Project Manual.

Plans, Specifications, and Contract Documents: Complete digital project bidding documents are available at www.questcdn.com. You may download the digital plan documents at no charge by inputting Quest project #6955630 on the websiteâs project search page. Please contact QuestCDN.com at 952-233-1632 or info@questcdn.com for assistance in free membership registration, downloading, and working with this digital project information. An optional paper set of the proposal forms and specifications for individual use may be obtained from the office of the Engineer, Beck Engineering Inc., 221 East Main St., Suite B, Cherokee, Iowa 51012. A refundable deposit of $100.00 is required for the documents. Deposit will be returned if plans and project manual are returned in good condition within 14 days after public hearing date.
NPHL-2
Acceptance or Rejection of Bids: The right to accept or reject any or all bids, and to waive informalities is reserved. The owner may award one or both divisions.
Time Frame: The work shall be completed as follows:
Work for the Tennis Court (Division I) shall be completed by September 30, 2020. Work for the Parking Lot (Division II) shall be completed by August 21, 2020.

By virtue of statutory authority, preference will be given to products and provisions grown and coal produced within the State of Iowa and to Iowa domestic labor to the extent lawfully required under Iowa statutes, providing that the award of the contract will be made to the lowest responsible bidder submitting the lowest acceptable bid, which shall be given without regard to state or local law whereby preference is given on factors other than the amount of the bid.
Cherokee Community School District
By: /s/ Laura Jones . President of the Board
ATTEST:
By: /s/ Kimberly Lingenfelter . Superintendent
NPHL-3

a.aria-label: Read more about Notice of Public Hearing and Letting

h3.a: Notice of Public Hearing and Letting

div.h4: 2020 Cherokee Community School District Track Improvements Project

div.p: NOTICE OF PUBLIC HEARING AND LETTING

for
2020 Cherokee Community School District Track Improvements Project

Public notice is hereby given that the School Board of the Cherokee Community School District, in Cherokee County, Iowa, will meet on April 20, 2020, at 5:30pm, at which time and place a public hearing will be held in the Cherokee Community School District board room in the Washington High School located at 600 West Bluff Street, Cherokee, Iowa 51012 on the proposed plans and specifications, form of contract and estimate of cost for the 2020 Cherokee Community School District Track Improvements Project for said School District. Sealed proposals will be received by the Superintendent of the Cherokee Community School District for the 2020 Cherokee Community School District Track Improvements Project until 1:30 P.M. on Friday, April 17, 2020 at the Washington High School, located at 600 West Bluff Street, Cherokee, IA 51012; at which time the bids will be publicly opened and read. Proposals will be acted on by the Cherokee Community School District School Board at the aforementioned public hearing or at such later time and place as may then be fixed.

Work to Be Done: 500 C.Y. of Topsoil, On-Site; 1000 C.Y. of Excavation, Class 10; 5849 S.Y. of Subgrade Preparation, 12â; 46 S.Y. of Modified Subbase, 2â; 5953 S.Y. of Modified Subbase, 4â; 475 L.F. of Storm Sewer, Trenched, Non-Perforated, Dual-Wall HDPE, 8â; 60 L.F. of Storm Sewer, Trenched, Non-Perforated, Dual-Wall HDPE, 18â; 272 L.F. of Removal of Storm Sewer,
â¤ 36â; 1 EA Special Pipe Connection for Storm Sewer, â¤ 36â; 2 EA Special Pipe Connection for Storm Sewer, â¥ 36â; 1307 L.F. of Subdrain, Perforated, Single-Wall HPDE, 6â; 2 EA Subdrain Outlets and Connection, HDPE, 6â; 5 EA Storm Sewer Intake, Nyloplast, 18â; 6 EA Removal Intake; 1 EA Remove, Salvage and Replace Existing Intake; 5761 S.Y. of Pavement, HMA, Base Course, 2.5â; 5673 S.Y. of Pavement, HMA, Surface Course, 1.5â; 1 LS HMA Pavement Samples and Testing; 47 S.Y. of Removal of Sidewalk; 46 S.Y. of Sidewalk, PCC, 5â; 5555 S.Y. of Pavement Removal, 1 LS Temporary Traffic Control; 0.6 AC of Conventional Seeding, Seeding, Fertilizing, and Hydro-Mulching; 1 LS Storm Water Pollution Prevention Plan, Management; 599 of L.F. Silt Fence, Installation and Removal; 100 L.F. of Silt Fence, Removal of Sediment; 120 S.Y. of Stabilized Construction Entrance; 18 EA Inlet Protection Device; 35 L.F. of Removal and Reinstallation of Existing Fence, Chain Link; 1 LS Mobilization; 1 LS Concrete Washout; 1398 L.F. of PCC Curb; 1 LS Electrical Conduit; 5873 S.Y. of Resilient Surfacing, Polyurethane Track Surface, 1/2â; 1 LS Striping; 105 L.F. Aco Sport, System 3000, Slot Channel Trench Drain System.
See Bid Form for exact quantities.

Proposals: All proposals shall be made on official proposal forms furnished by the Engineer and shall contain worded and figured prices for the work bid on. All proposals shall be plainly legible, sealed, and addressed to the Cherokee Community Schools, Attn: Kimberly Lingenfelter, Superintendent, 600 West Bluff Street, Cherokee, IA 51012. Bidder shall submit a Bidder Status Form with their bid. Failure to submit a fully completed Bidder Status Form with the bid may result in the bid being deemed unresponsive and rejected. A certified check or a bid bond of a reputable bonding company authorized to do business in the State of Iowa in an amount not less than ten percent (10%) of the total amount of the bid shall be included in a separate sealed envelope, plainly marked âbid bondâ. The bid guarantee shall be forfeited as liquidated damages if the successful bidder fails proper execution.

The checks or bid bonds of the lowest two or more bidders may be held for the earlier of 7 days after the effective date of the agreement or 61 days after the bid opening, whereupon Bid Security furnished by such bidders will be returned. Other checks or bid bonds will be returned after the tabulation of bids is completed.
NPHL-1

Performance and Payment Bonds: The successful bidder must execute performance and payment bonds, each in an amount equal to one hundred (100%) percent of the contract amount to ensure a timely, efficient, and complete performance. The bonds shall be issued from a reputable bonding company authorized to do business in the State of Iowa.

Liquidated Damages: Liquidated damages will be assessed the contractor in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per working day that the work remains uncompleted after the end of the contract period with due allowances for extensions due to conditions beyond the control of the contractor.
Withdrawal of Bids: No submitted bids may be withdrawn for a period of thirty (30) days from the scheduled closing time for the receipt of bids.

Payment: The Contractor will be paid monthly in an amount equal to ninety-five percent (95%) of the Work completed during the previous month according to the Engineerâs estimate. The final payment will be made not less than thirty (30) days after completion of the Work and acceptance by the City. No final payment will be due until the Contractor has certified that the materials, labor, and services have been paid for in accordance with the Project Manual.

Plans, Specifications, and Contract Documents: Complete digital project bidding documents are available at www.questcdn.com. You may download the digital plan documents at no charge by inputting Quest project #6957612 on the websiteâs project search page. Please contact QuestCDN.com at 952-233-1632 or info@questcdn.com for assistance in free membership registration, downloading, and working with this digital project information. An optional paper set of the proposal forms and specifications for individual use may be obtained from the office of the Engineer, Beck Engineering Inc., 221 East Main St., Suite B, Cherokee, Iowa 51012. A refundable deposit of $100.00 is required for the documents. Deposit will be returned if plans and project manual are returned in good condition within 14 days after public hearing date.
Acceptance or Rejection of Bids: The right to accept or reject any or all bids and to waive informalities is reserved.
Time Frame: The work shall be completed as follows:

Substantial Completion: Grading, Storm Sewer, HMA Track, and Seeding shall be completed by August 21, 2020
Final Completion: Resilient Surfacing and Striping shall be completed by September 30, 2020

By virtue of statutory authority, preference will be given to products and provisions grown and coal produced within the State of Iowa and to Iowa domestic labor to the extent lawfully required under Iowa statutes, providing that the award of the contract will be made to the lowest responsible bidder submitting the lowest acceptable bid, which shall be given without regard to state or local law whereby preference is given on factors other than the amount of the bid.
Cherokee Community School District
By: /s/ Laura Jones . President of the Board
ATTEST:
By: /s/ Kimberly Lingenfelter . City Administrator
NPHL-2

div.p: Â
Â

p.b: Early Childhood Learning Center
Preschool Registration Information

div.p: Â

p.b: The Early Childhood Learning Center is accepting applications for the 2020-21 school year.Â If your child will be four-years-old by September 15, 2020 they will be eligible to receive free preschool programming through the Cherokee Community School District.Â Â Â Â Â

div.p: Â

p.b: Link for the online registration form:Â ECLC 2020-21 Application
A paper copy of the registration form may be printed from this document or picked up from the Roosevelt school office.Â Â

div.p: Â

p.b: ECLC follows accreditation standards of both the Iowa Department of Education and the Iowa Department of Human Services.
All preschool classrooms are led by teachers with four-year bachelorâs degrees in the areas of early childhood education.Â Â
The program uses Creative Curriculum.Â
Classes are held Monday through Friday as half day programming.Â The program offers a morning or an afternoon class option.
In general, the ECLC calendar follows the district calendar of days off with a few additional days off for professional development specific to the ECLC program needs.Â Â
In-town transportation provided by the Cherokee CSD.

Please apply if you have a 3 year old that you are interested in having attend our preschool.Â Decisions for accepting 3 year olds into the program will be made in April after consideration of capacity to serve the 3 year old students.Â Â
Â

If you are interested in having your child participate in a quality preschool program, you may apply online or pick up an application at the Roosevelt Elementary School, or call 712-225-6760 for more information. Applications are also available through the district website (www.ccsd.k12.ia.us). For district planning purposes, applications are due to the school by March 12, 2020.Â Applications submitted later will be considered if there is room for students in our classes.Â Â

div.p: Â

p.b: Eligibility Requirements for the Statewide Voluntary Preschool Program (Iowa Department of Education Requirements)
Child must be 4 years old on or before September 15th
Child must be a resident of Iowa
Child does not have to live within the school district boundaries
Requirements of the participating preschools:
Must have a licensed teacher licensed through the state of Iowa in Early Childhood Education
Must have no more than 10 students per adult with a limitation that each classroom will not exceed 20 students.
Must provide a minimum of 10 hours of curriculum based programming per week.
Must provide a minimum of 35 sq feet of usable space per child in each of the primary indoor activity areas.

Each preschool site is required to adhere to the guidelines and report to the state adherence to the guidelines in the form of a Site Self-assessment.Â Within this assessment the following areas are addressed:
Building positive relationships among teachers, families and children through socialization, consistent harmonious classrooms, and development of self-regulation in each student.

Curriculum content areas for cognitive development in science, language development, early literacy development, mathematics, technology, expression and appreciation for the arts, health and safety, and social studies.

The teacherâs ability to organize the time and space available, control the classroom through addressing challenging or disruptive behaviors, sight supervision, ability to recognize each studentâs interests and needs, as well as their ability to deepen the students understanding of curriculum topics and then build on their skills and knowledge.

Maintaining an assessment plan to chart the growth on all areas of childrenâs development and learning including cognitive skills, language, social-emotional development, approaches to learning health, and physical development (including self-help skills)
Adherence to approved nutrition and health requirements of all children and staff to protect them from preventable illness and injury.

Open communication between teacher or site and the studentâs family through a variety of formal and informal strategies such as conversations, written communications, open houses and parent-teacher conferences.

Being the link between families and community agencies by maintaining a current list of child and family support services available to families such as health, mental health, oral health, nutrition, child welfare, parenting programs, early intervention/special education screening and assessment services, and basic needs such as housing and child care subsidies.
Adherence to specific guidelines for space and a variety of age appropriate and developmentally appropriate equipment, furniture and hands on materials for both indoor and outdoor play.

Leadership and managerial requirements of the program as well as fiscal accountability policies, health, nutrition, and safety policies, and personnel hiring policies for support staff there to assist the teachers.

Must provide accountability to the state through annual reports designed to monitor all aspects of the program including but not limited to cognitive growth of each student, spending of grant funds, and eligibility of teachers and support staff.

div.p: Â
Â

div.style: width: 70%; margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto;margin-top: 5px;font-size: 11px; line-height: 1.2;
div.p: Equal Opportunity at Cherokee Community Schools

The Cherokee Community School District offers career and technical programs in the following service areas: Business Education, Health Occupations Education, Family and Consumer Sciences Education, and Industrial Education. It is the policy of Cherokee Community School District not to discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, creed, socioeconomic status, religion, sex, marital status, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, or disability in educational programs or employment. There is a grievance procedure for processing complaints of discrimination. If you have questions or a grievance related to this policy, please contact:

Kimberly Lingenfelter, Equity Coordinator
600 W. Bluff Street, Cherokee, IA 51012
(712) 225-6767 or klingenfelter@ccsd.k12.ia.us

p.a: This institution is an equal opportunity provider.
